I still have faith. We can be worthy of the promise laid out in our Constitution. 

We in the Senate have the power to protect our democracy. We have no excuse not to use it.

1479130175665229825.text:
We can’t allow it. Through the January 6 Commission and the Justice Department, we must hold accountable those responsible - including those at the top. 

And we must pass the Freedom to Vote Act, fulfilling the promise of our nation, giving the people the power to decide.

1479130022258651142.text:
The insurrection failed, but the fight continues nationwide.

1479129707933315072.text: I’ve thought a lot about this day over the past year. It’s important we are clear about what happened, how it connects to what has happened since, and what needs to happen next.

1479129311433084941.text:
On January 6, I woke up early. 

I wrote down a few thoughts and then my husband Archie popped the anxious question, “Are you going to be ok?” 

For sure I told him—the United States Capitol is one of the safest places in the country. Little did I know.

Do I believe we can get there? Yes. It’s going to be tough. 

But if we focus on what we can and should do, we have a fighting chance.

1433564503229280257.text: Republicans stole two Supreme Court seats and as demonstrated by this decision, much of the current Court is dangerously unmoored from any reasonable principles of legal analysis.

1433564502101004288.text: And if we do that successfully, and we get a few more seats, we should use our power to eliminate the filibuster and expand the court.

1433564499190108167.text: Expanding our majorities in Congress will be hard. There’s a good chance we could lose one or both Houses in 2022. But remember that a strong majority of the public agrees with us on reproductive rights. It’s a voting issue and a winning one. So it’s our job to make the case.

1433564497847926784.text: The reality is that if a vote was brought up tomorrow to change or eliminate the filibuster or reform or add seats to the Supreme Court, it would fail. I wish it were different. We don’t have the numbers and that’s what we have to focus on changing.

1433564496484868099.text: So we’re going to fight. But I want to be clear that there is not a magical lever of power we could pull but are avoiding. We can tweet and send out press releases stating our positions as much as we like, but that’s not a strategy.

1433564495226490882.text:
First off, let’s be very clear about what‘s happening. This is the culmination of a 40 year effort by Republicans to radically remake the courts with the help of dark money and the Federalist Society.

1417514138029461509.text:
The key is important groups have supported clean electricity standards.

Utility companies like how they lowers costs (clean energy is not just clean—it's cheap); labor unions like the jobs created; and environmental groups want to combat climate change with bold legislation.

1417514136611790852.text:
It’s simple: we set a goal to get to 100% clean electricity (net zero carbon pollution) as soon as possible. And then we help power generators - from the big utilities to your local coop - make the shift to clean power.
 
Sounds great! But can it pass?
 
It can! Here's why:

1417514135378710533.text:
Most Americans already support what we need to do—move to a clean energy future—and fast.
 
The best, most effective way to do this is to invest in a clean electricity standard. How does that work?

1417514134132957188.text:
Climate change isn't some pie-in-the-sky problem we can deal with later; it's happening right now.

1405693134047268868.text: All of us at the White House today celebrated this moment, and also understood that today is only one more paving stone on the long path toward justice and freedom we need to build together.

1405693132243615748.text: I’ve gotten to know Ms. Lee over the last few years, and have followed her leadership. Her persistence and joy is absolutely infectious. 1405693115583848448.text: Our President celebrated 95-year-old Ms. Opal Lee, who has organized and advocated for Juneteenth for decades, dropping down on one knee to greet her.

1405693113960742916.text: Our remarkable Vice President, Kamala Harris, the first woman and first Black Vice President, spoke today with deep conviction about the meaning of Juneteenth, and the work we have ahead.

1405693109711876096.text: It was built by enslaved people, and today Congress still denies the city’s residents—many of them Black—the right to be represented in Congress.

1405693107191025669.text: Here are a few impressions: The White House is a small big place. It’s a beautiful building filled with grand rooms, cramped offices, private places and some of the most public and famous views in the world.

1405693105777561604.text: We didn’t know until minutes before our bill passed the Senate that it would even get done, but we did it—all of a sudden after decades of organizing and advocating by so many.

1405693104234156039.text:
Today Juneteenth becomes a federal holiday, & I stood behind @VP & @POTUS to watch our bill be signed into law.

This has been a hard year, filled with trauma and worry, loss and hardship. So it feels good to celebrate this important & unifying moment.

1405633342108733446.text:

1390040883337338881.text: Today, on the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous People, Congress should reauthorize #VAWA and take up my Justice for Native Survivors Act to restore Tribal authority to prosecute sexual violence against Native people and get justice for survivors.

1389588295286497282.text:
I'll have more to say soon but I want folks to know that even in the midst of this health crisis, I believe there's hope on the horizon for those who struggle with mental illness. But we in the Senate have to do the work to help make that vision a reality. 

Time to get to work.

1389588178768744453.text:
I'm announcing I'm rolling out three bills this month addressing the mental health crisis in America. The theme that unites them all: access to resources. 

When I struggled with depression, resources were there for me. Many Americans don't get those, let's change that.

1389588049881882625.text:
I'm grateful I got help, but I share this because I want anyone suffering from a mental health issue to know they are not alone. We can all help break the stigma around talking about this.

But also as a Senator, I recognize my unique position. And I want to use it.

1389587894684291073.text:
Did I live happily ever after? Not quite. Mental illness isn't a box where you're healthy or not—it's a spectrum. 

I struggled again in my 30s as a young mom. But after a few years of treatment, I improved and know I can turn to it if I need it again.

Happier IS possible.

1389587779928080386.text:
When my roommate first talked to me about how I hadn't been myself, I was in denial. But eventually, I realized it made sense to go see a counselor. I didn't know what to expect and honestly, I was embarrassed. 

But the experience changed my life.

1389587659123744768.text:
When it started in college, I thought it was just a rough patch. But at some point, it got harder to cope with life's daily challenges. 

Everybody who's wrestled with depression has their metaphor, but many can identify with the sensation of color draining out of the world.

1389587576055599108.text:
I want to share something personal for Mental Health Awareness month. We need more understanding and help for the millions of Americans who struggle with mental illness.

I'm not saying that just because I'm a Senator, I'm saying that as someone who has suffered from depression.

1387594873910538240.text: Tonight, President Biden again showed that the Biden-Harris White House believes in government that fights for all families & working people, not just a few at the top. I look forward to continuing to partner on this work, & expanding opportunity for Minnesotans & all Americans.

1387594873163952128.text: In addition to childcare and early education, President Biden touched on the progress we’ve made when it comes to combating the coronavirus pandemic, and the progress we still need to make on police reform, gun safety, and tackling climate change.

1387594872434171907.text: I’ve heard from many Minnesotans about the need for affordable, high-quality childcare bc we know early ed is fundamental for families & our economy. So I’m glad President Biden unveiled his American Families Plan & spoke tonight about how it would make investments we badly need.

1387594871700140032.text: Hearing Chad’s story and the experiences in Minnesota inspired me to tackle this and work with partners in congress to deliver historic funding to help stabilize this essential sector.

1387594870949351425.text: Chad & I connected in the early days of the pandemic about the crisis MN childcare providers & families were facing. Childcare faced huge challenges before the pandemic, but was pushed to the brink and in some cases over the edge.

1387594869867225090.text: New Horizon Academy is one of the many childcare providers that the American Rescue Plan will help. While I wish Chad could have been here in-person, it was an honor for him to be my guest.

1387594868390825991.text: I want to thank Chad Dunkley for being my virtual guest at President Biden’s Joint Address to Congress tonight. Chad serves as CEO of New Horizon Academy, a family-owned company in Minnesota that has been serving young kids for 50 years.

1387560634112430080.text: Parents, kids, our communities and providers like Chad deserve nothing less.

1387560632304738318.text: Tonight, I'm looking forward to hearing @POTUS talk more about his plans in the #AmericanFamiliesPlan, and I am so glad that childcare and early education are getting the top-billing these issues deserve.

1387560630778044420.text: But there is still much more to be done to make the big, structural investments we need to provide affordable, quality, care for kids and families.

1387560629226123264.text: The bulk of that came from the #AmericanRescuePlan, where we worked together to get $39 billion to stabilize childcare after the hit it took with the pandemic.

1387560627711979533.text: I've been proud to work with incredible partners in Congress @PattyMurray and @SenWarren to help deliver historic funding to help stabilize this essential sector with more than $50 billion.

1387560626147495939.text: As parents know, childcare faced huge challenges before the pandemic. But with COVID it was pushed to the brink and in some cases over the edge. Hearing from childcare providers in Minnesota inspired me to tackle this issue head on.

1387560624528494592.text: I'll never forget the emotion in his voice as he shared his story, what was happening to the childcare centers he runs and providers across Minnesota (as revenue plummeted virtually overnight).

1387560622733287430.text:
It's great to see President Biden unveil his American Families Plan today.
 
My guest tonight Chad Dunkley and I connected in the early days of the pandemic, on March 19 the first week of remote work, about the crisis childcare providers and families were facing.

1387412997019250690.text:
Affordable, high-quality childcare and early ed is fundamental for families and our economy. And it's something that we've underinvested in for too long.

Glad the Biden-Harris American Families Plan, being unveiled today, makes significant investments. Let's get to work.

1387203000955977733.text:

1385351220559286272.text: Let’s move this celebration to the halls of Congress by passing my Clean Electricity Standard, which will get us to net zero carbon emissions from power plants. And let’s do it while supporting great union jobs.  We can even do it without raising energy prices.

1385351218399166464.text: For Earth Day 2021, how about we agree that we shouldn’t subsidize fossil fuel companies anymore to spew out carbon pollution. It’s like we are paying companies to pollute.

1385351214909566999.text:
In 1970, I was 12, and went out with a trash bag to pick up litter.  I was outraged.  Who was trashing my community?
 
On Earth Day in 2021,  It’s a little more complicated, but I’m still outraged.  Who is trashing our planet?

1385351212749541376.text:
On the first Earth Day in 1970, 20 million Americans took to the streets, parks and classrooms to demonstrate against the impacts of air and water pollution. That was 10% of the US and would be 33 million people today.
 
Where is everyone – let’s do it.

1385341472556425218.text: And strength be with those of us who have the power to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. We need to use our power to make progress.

What if we rethink public safety so that Black and Brown people, and all people, truly feel safe and protected in their homes, neighborhoods and communities?

This is the work ahead of all of us.

1384616637794504709.text:
And we can change them.

What if this verdict is the beginning of a transformation in public safety for Minnesota and our country, where we move past the warrior model of policing and toward a model of truly protecting and serving?

1384616636179755013.text:
He was talking about the deep and persistent inequities in housing, health care, policing and the criminal justice system, and economic opportunity that people of color experience in my state.
 
These inequities exist, not only in Minnesota, but all across our country.

1384616634598449156.text:
I can’t stop thinking about all the Black and Brown people denied their civil rights and denied their lives, where there was no accountability.
 
Last week a reporter interviewing me referred to Minnesota as “the Jim Crow of the North.” Devastating.

1384616631708622849.text: Millions of people took to the streets because we couldn’t look away from the reality of George Floyd’s murder and we could see change had to come.

1357449598864883715.text: Lena O. Smith fought against racial discrimination through her work as a lawyer in mid-20th-century Minnesota. She was the first black female lawyer in the state and went on to become the first female president of the NAACP Minneapolis chapter. Lena persevered like no other.

1357449596918779904.text: Toni Stone grew up in St. Paul, Minnesota where she would play baseball with the boys in her neighborhood. Although her love of baseball was considered “unladylike”, Toni went on to become the first woman to play as a regular on an American professional baseball team.

1357449595777875971.text: Nellie Stone Johnson, a civil rights activist and organizer, was the first black elected official in Minneapolis. She was instrumental in the creation of the Fair Employment Practices Dept., which was the first of its kind in the US. Nellie was a champion of working people.

I'll close by saying that this pandemic only exacerbated the childcare crisis. I've been working on this issue my entire time in the Senate—the way we do childcare in this country needs an overhaul.

So let's make sure childcare survives this crisis AND fix the system long-term.

1303755147336708099.text: This isn't just the right thing to do, it's also an investment. Working moms contribute a huge amount to our workforce, if communities lack childcare, we are risking hamstringing our economic recovery.

1303755146095140865.text:
With more emergency funding, we can avert this crisis. We can allow providers to keep staff on payroll, get PPE, and get assistance for other expenses needed to make childcare work.

Our bill has 50 billion in funding for this effect.

1303755144748838913.text: I'll touch on number two in this thread. Mass closures are a serious issue. Childcare has always had thin margins and an early survey indicated nearly half of all providers could not survive a two week shutdown.

1303755143490539520.text:
Our plan has three pieces.  

1) Providing support to providers caring for the children of those fighting this pandemic on the frontlines. 
2) Preventing mass permanent closures in the childcare system.
3) Shoring up the system to make it work better in the future.

1303755142068666368.text:
Also want to point out this crisis has been particularly hard on working moms. The @NYTimes had a feature on this recently, linked it here.

1225172995859189760.text: There is nothing inevitable about democracy. It’s not a natural state, it’s a state we have to fight for. The fight for democracy and our Constitution has chosen us in this moment and it’s our job to rise to the moment. (5/7)

1225172993564979205.text: Now, we go forward. This trial has changed us, but it doesn’t change the core value of America that no one is above the law, including and most especially the President. (4/7)

1225172988674310145.text: It was not a suspenseful moment, but if felt as weighty as when I first raised my right hand and pledged to provide impartial justice. I know that is what I did. (2/7)

1225172986275278850.text:

1223238580744740865.text: Lot of talk this morning from Republicans about bipartisan norms for Senate impeachment trials. What about the norm that trials have witnesses—what’s different now, Republicans?

1223055394030923777.text: (4/4) And about half the people in the Senate chamber have some version of a cough or cold. It’s like a petri dish. Even Chief Justice Roberts was clearing his throat. One theory is that we all used the same pen to sign the oath book, and here we are.

1223055393045262337.text: (3/4) For me, it’s clear: why would anyone in the Senate vote against witnesses, only to find out later what Bolton knows about what really happened? That would be hard to explain to your grandchildren. The truth always comes out.

1223055392059596800.text: (2/4) We have a few more hours of questions—we’ve had over 13 hours. I hope for a little more insight after another long day. Everyone is looking ahead to the discussion tomorrow of witnesses.

1223055390851637248.text: (1/4) Impeachment trial day 9. Woke up this morning after about 4 hours of sleep, & all I could think about was what happened yesterday. Was breathtaking to watch President’s defenders transform completely from saying President did nothing wrong to President can do nothing wrong.

1222686903499182080.text: (3/3) It’s kind of nuts to hear the President’s lawyers threaten that hearing witnesses in the Senate will take too much time. During the Clinton impeachment, it took the Senate one day to depose each witness. How is having a fair trial too time consuming?

1222686902530314243.text: (2/3) My first red notebook is almost full, and my fingers are covered with blue ink from my felt tip pen. It’s interesting to hear the two sides go back and forth, and there have been some good questions. But...

1222686901422804993.text: (1/3) I’ve been sharing my thoughts each day of the impeachment trial, and here’s day 8: We are in the question and answer portion of the trial. So far senators have asked over 50 questions and we have another few hours to go.

1222290998119817216.text: (3/3) A lot of you have reached out to me in the past few days, and you overwhelmingly support witnesses and documents.  We cannot be afraid of the facts.

1222290995875729410.text:
(2/3) I have a lot of questions, but first among them is this: why are the President’s lawyers opposed to witnesses and documents? 

Why would the Senate not want John Bolton to testify under oath? Why would we oppose asking Mick Mulvaney to tell us what he knows?

1222290993799745536.text:
(1/3) At the end of day #7, we have finished hearing the presentations from the President’s lawyers. 

For the next two days, senators will have an opportunity to ask questions of the House Managers and the President’s lawyers.

1222270306951127040.text: Thanks for having me on @AprilDRyan. https://t.co/nAmb7MPSU2

1222261744489373696.text: Agreed. Bolton communicated with the President directly—if this trial is going to be fair, we need to hear what he had to say. https://t.co/xQn3PYqBdd

1221959520798367745.text: (5/5) Lawyers really doubled down on Hunter Biden & went so far as to say that Obama should have been impeached, using House standard. Honestly it was bizarre. Their close was more like a preview of political ads this fall—both negative & positive. The message was not too subtle.

1221959519565238273.text: (4/5) Makes it even more clear that we must have witnesses & documents to have fair trial. I don’t see how a member of the Senate could refuse to hear Bolton testify under oath now that we know something about what’s out there. This information will come out—why not hear it now?

1221959518302674945.text: (3/5) It was also surreal to have no discussion at all of the big news this weekend, that Bolton in his manuscript apparently makes it clear that the President did want an investigation into the Bidens and the 2016 election in exchange for releasing the aid.

1221959517493190663.text: (2/5) Was surreal to see Kenneth Starr review history and precedent of impeachment. One of his points was that we have been in what he called an age of impeachment that we should leave behind. Not a lot of irony in his presentation, given his lead role in the Clinton impeachment.

1221959516872433664.text: (1/5) Today is Day #6. It’s been a second day of hearing from the President’s lawyers. A couple things stand out:

1221915327392559105.text: Today, on #HolocaustRemembranceDay, I’m thinking about how we must all do our part to remember the unspeakable horrors of the Holocaust while rooting out Anti-Semitism and hatred wherever it exists. #NeverAgain

1221216679100919808.text:
(6/6) On the good side, the President’s lawyers were civil and measured, which I think will help us all listen with the “empathetic attentiveness” that the Senate Chaplin has encouraged.

It will be good to have a day or so to think on all this, and clear my head for next week.

1221216676949172225.text: (5/6) I’ve never been a member of a jury before—I’ve never even been called for jury duty. But it never dawned on me that my 1st trial would be in the U.S. Senate, & it would not include even this most basic element—witnesses, & ability for both sides to cross examine witnesses.

1221216675707654144.text: (4/6) If the President’s lawyers really believe the witnesses we’ve heard from so far don’t have all the facts about what happened here, why not hear from the witnesses, and see the documents, that could clear all this up? I don’t think this question is going to go away.

1221216674667470848.text: (3/6) What was interesting to me is how their presentation makes the case even stronger for why this trial needs witnesses and the documents.

1221216673199542272.text: (2/6) After three days of comprehensive, thorough review of the facts and evidence from the House Managers, the President’s lawyers tried to to poke holes in the House Managers’ arguments.

1221216671823814656.text: (1/6) Day #5 was a short day, just two hours of presentation from the President’s lawyers. After the session I went up to the gallery with my colleagues Tammy Duckworth, Jeff Merkley, and Leader Chuck Schumer to do a quick press response to the proceedings.

1220874178863255555.text: Tomorrow the President’s counsel will take up their presentation. I’ll let you know my impressions. In the meantime, thinking of questions I want answers to, & I continue to hope we will hear from witnesses & see documents that will allow us to know the truth. Which is our right.

1220874178112499713.text: I’m working long hours, so Archie is coming to the Capitol and my colleague Senator Pat Leahy has offered his historic Capitol Hill office for a brief celebration. Thank you Pat, and happy birthday Archie.

1220874176648679427.text: Day #4, & I’m providing just a short note today because I’m taking my dinner break—30 minutes!—to celebrate my husband Archie’s 65th birthday. I’m usually in Washington without Archie, so it’s a real treat to have him here.

1220749136716345350.text: I’m sharing my notes each day of the impeachment trial to help give folks a sense of what it’s like to be in the Senate during this historic moment—here’s last night’s: https://t.co/Vy397lpBH8

1220522464578588677.text:
I can’t comment on the content of the document. What I can say is classifying a document solely because it contains embarrassing or damaging information is not a good reason.

I’m heading back on the floor for another several hours.

1220522463571910657.text: One other thing: This morning before the Trial started, I reviewed a classified document with a statement from Vice President Pence’s senior aide, describing a telephone conversation between the Vice President and Ukrainian President Zelensky.

1220522462598914049.text: The White House lawyers argue in their 171-page brief that abuse of power is not impeachable. Let’s just say it’s hard to find a legal expert to support their position. But we’ll learn more about that when they begin their presentation.

1220522461344731136.text: The House managers provided an excellent review of the constitutional rationale, history and precedent for impeachment for a President’s abuse of power. Even my colleagues with law degrees found it fascinating and full of good information.

1220522459486703617.text: Little more than halfway through Day #3. The Senate Chaplin began his opening prayer by urging us not just to hear but to also practice empathetic attentiveness. & to remember our friendships in the Senate. The Chaplin can always be counted on to appeal to our higher principles.

1220155504904765441.text:
Lastly, I will say that watching the tapes of the President INVITING foreign interference in our elections—including from China—I asked myself, “is this a big deal?”

And I’ve come to the conclusion that yes, it is a very big deal.

1220155504040796162.text: 3) The distrustful way Rudy Giuliani has pursued the President’s private political interests, mixing with foreign policy in ways that can only be described as corrupt and antithetical to American values.

1220155503059390464.text: 2) It’s compelling to see how many facts link to Russia—the false theory that Ukraine, and not Russia, interfered in our 2016 election; how withholding aid weakened Ukraine in its fight with Russia; and how Russia interfered in the 2016 election to benefit Donald Trump; and

1220155502161809414.text: 1) The facts aren’t really in dispute. Even the President’s lawyers haven’t challenged them so far.

1220155501192908800.text:
The House managers’ presentation, led by Congressman Adam Schiff, was a strong summation of the facts and the core issues the Senate faces. Now the House managers are plowing through the timeline and key facts.
We aren’t done for today just yet, but here are my thoughts:

1220155500148482048.text: I’m keeping notes in a red notebook—kind of a stream of consciousness of quotes, observations, and things to remember. I’m starting to think about questions I want to ask.

1220155499087388674.text: Day 2, after a long night yesterday, and you can feel people settling into this new world of hours sitting on the Senate floor, listening and taking notes. And maybe a catnap or two (not naming names).

1220017914742497283.text:
And THEN, graciously allow a debate on whether witnesses should be called, even though the trial is basically over. All the while, talk about fairness and hope America doesn’t notice.

I think America is noticing.

1220017912829923328.text:
Based on how things went yesterday, here’s Mitch McConnell's plan for how to hold an impeachment trial:
    
First, tell the prosecution that they can’t call any witnesses.  Not any. Tell them to argue their case and then let the jury (that’s us) ask questions.

1219780830924591105.text: 3) McConnell's move to table seems designed to protect his members from a "no" vote on including documents and witnesses for this trial, but I bet Americans will see what's really happening here.

1219780830119198722.text:
I’m thinking as I’m writing this:

1) We should be rigorously prepared.

2) We shouldn’t be afraid of the facts and…

1219780828957478919.text:
It's a good strategy, said one of my colleagues, to "pre-unwrap" cough lozenges to keep from making noise.

There is tea, coffee, and treats in the cloakroom.

1219780828080869376.text:
The President's lawyers seemed to be speaking to an audience of one. On questions of whether the Senate should call for witnesses and documents, they talked about Mueller, Pelosi, and Schiff.

Sometimes it came off as a bit incoherent. They read from notes and seemed unprepared.

1219780827254611968.text:
The House managers today relentlessly plowed through questions about witnesses and documents, and asked us essentially "Why WOULDN'T you want to know this? Why WOULDN'T you want to see the documents?"

I agree.

1219780826260525062.text:
As promised, I have some more of my notes from the impeachment trial.

By 6 p.m. on the first day, you can start to see some themes:

1219409977208659969.text:
Then, two day, 24-hour marathons for presenting each side. Would you want your lawyer to be required to represent you under these circumstances?

It’s outrageous and a clear sign McConnell has no intention of holding the fair trial that Americans expect.

1219409976403341312.text:
Just reading proposed GOP impeachment trial rules, which are ridiculous. 

There’s nothing in this resolution that requires hearing witnesses or admitting evidence—which is unlike any trial I’ve ever seen.

1218218506396803078.text: In the Senate cloakrooms we now have carefully labeled cubbies to put our phones, iPads and smart watches aside while we go onto the floor. You can tell it’s hard for some of us to leave them there.

1218218503892819968.text: Looking out at my colleagues, I was struck by how rare it is that we are all on the floor together, sitting down, and focused on one thing. What would the Senate be like if we came together like this more often?

1218218501493739524.text: Senate staff on both sides of the aisle made sure we all lined up to sign the oath in the correct order. That was the only time all day that Democrats and Republicans mixed in together. We need to mix more.

1218218498989678595.text: When Roberts came onto the floor the air changed. He looked, not pained, exactly, but as if he also felt the weight of history.

1218218496968011776.text:
After lunch, the women were thinking logistics. 

It’s freezing in the chamber, should I bring a shawl? One of my colleagues plans to wear long underwear. The stools under our desks are helpful - the chairs of the Senate were designed for the likes of Abe Lincoln.

1218218494677962752.text:
When the House managers came onto the floor, I felt the weight of history, and a small catch in my throat. 

It was a relief to hear @RepAdamSchiff present the articles dispassionately, clearly, and rationally. We are all wondering what the President’s lawyers will bring.

1218218492635353094.text: From where I sit, close to the doors in the second row of seats, I can see the faces of most of my colleagues: serious, focused, aware that the country is watching.

1218218490718498816.text: Every day during the impeachment trial I’ll be taking notes, which I’ll share some of here.  Yesterday was day 1.

1184946921946931201.text: I urge Mitch McConnell to allow the Senate to take up the Resolution condemning the President’s decision, which passed the House this week with wide bipartisan support. The guns may have stopped for now, but the President’s leadership remains clearly dangerous for our nation.

1184946919560372230.text: But we should remember that the events of the last week are a catastrophe of the President’s making. Those ISIS terrorists, once held captive, are now free, and no ceasefire will change that. And that is unforgivable.

1184946917165408256.text: Whenever the guns stop firing this is good news, and we should all hope that the violence unleashed by the US withdrawal from the Syrian borderlands stops for good.

1184946914837569536.text: After a breathtaking week, we are now told that Vice President Pence has brokered a temporary “pause” in Syria, on terms that effectively hand Turkey a victory while forcing the Kurds to surrender.

1184946912841125888.text: This is not a game show, it is literally life or death, and the consequences of this dangerous decision have played out with terrible speed.

1184946910756556801.text:
Kurdish civilians have lost their lives because of the President’s unilateral, impulsive decision. 100s of ISIS terrorists & their families are free because of his decision.

Because of the President’s decision, Russia, Iran, Syria’s murderous leader Assad, and ISIS are stronger.

1184946908827136000.text: Trump’s recent decision to peremptorily withdraw US troops from Syria, with no plan to keep ISIS and terrorism under control, blindsiding our friends and allies, as well as our military and diplomatic service corps, makes the world a much more dangerous place, for Americans.

1184946906906144773.text: That’s what happens with terrorism, and ISIS. It’s what happens with Russia’s aggressive attacks on our election system. It’s what happens when Iran threatens our friends and allies in the middle east, like Israel.

1184946904528019457.text:
We live in a dangerous world. 

These dangers may seem to be thousands of miles away on the map. But if there’s one thing we should have learned over these last few years, it’s that long-distance danger can erupt close to home with no warning.

1184946902560858114.text:
I have some thoughts on what is unfolding in Syria, and why Trump’s leadership is so dangerous for our nation.
